conclusion: To determine the trend of acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2 from the velocity-time (v-t) graph, follow these steps:
The x-axis represents time (t). The y-axis represents velocity (v). The curve represents the velocity of object B over time.
The red tangent lines are drawn at different points on the curve. These lines represent the instantaneous rate of change of velocity with respect to time at those points, which is the acceleration.

premise: The slope of a tangent line on a v-t graph gives the acceleration at that specific time.
conclusion: The slope of the first tangent line (left side) is negative, implying negative acceleration.

premise: The slope of a tangent line on a v-t graph gives the acceleration at that specific time.
conclusion: The slope of the second tangent line (middle) is zero or very small, suggesting zero or minimal acceleration.

premise: The slope of a tangent line on a v-t graph gives the acceleration at that specific time.
conclusion: The slope of the third tangent line (right side) is positive, indicating positive acceleration.

premise: Initially, object B has negative acceleration (slowing down). As time progresses, the acceleration becomes zero or minimal, indicating a moment of constant velocity. Finally, the acceleration becomes positive, meaning the object starts speeding up.
conclusion: The acceleration of object B starts negative, reaches zero or minimal, and then becomes positive as time progresses from 0 to t2.
